study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of stem cell therapy in treating diabetic foot ulcers, focusing on outcomes such as ulcer healing, amputation rates, and pain-free walking distance.
results_summary: The study found that stem cell therapy significantly improved ulcer healing rates, reduced amputation rates, and increased pain-free walking distance compared to control groups, with no significant association between stem cell infusion and adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers (766 participants across 19 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and effectiveness of two perturbation-based balance training paradigms (PBTtreadmill and PBTstability) in reducing fall risk and improving balance in fall-prone older adults.
results_summary: Both PBTtreadmill and PBTstability were feasible and effective, with PBTstability showing significant improvements in balance ability and PBTtreadmill improving reactive balance. No severe adverse events were reported, and adherence rates were high.
population_specificity: Fall-prone older adults (mean age 74.9 ± 6.0 years) with verified fall risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of walking as an intervention for preventing and managing frailty and fragility fractures, compared to other exercise-based approaches.
results_summary: Walking as a singular intervention has limited benefits for frailty and fragility fracture prevention and management. Multifaceted exercise programs, including resistance training and balance exercises, are more effective.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk of or experiencing frailty and fragility fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of remote qigong intervention versus a combined exercise regimen (including walking) on quality of life and physical fitness in post-surgical breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that walking, as part of the combined exercise rehabilitation group, was used alongside resistance training, but specific efficacy results for walking alone were not detailed in the abstract. The primary outcomes focused on quality of life and physical fitness metrics.
population_specificity: Post-surgical breast cancer patients.
effective_dosage: Walking was performed outside of the twice-weekly 30-minute resistance training sessions (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the Tack Endovascular System for treating vascular dissection following angioplasty in the superficial femoral artery and/or proximal popliteal artery.
results_summary: The study found that Tack deployment was safe and effective, with a 95.4% survival rate at 24 months, no major amputations, and 77.7% freedom from clinically driven target lesion revascularization. Rutherford classification, ankle-brachial index, and quality of life significantly improved compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Patients with Rutherford classification 2 to 4 and de novo or non-stented restenotic lesions in the superficial femoral artery and/or proximal popliteal artery who developed dissection after angioplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the clinical and genetic spectrum of ANO5-related muscle disease, including genotype-phenotype correlations and motor outcomes such as walking aid use.
results_summary: The study found that ANO5-related muscle disease predominantly affects males, with worse motor outcomes, including earlier use of walking aids. No significant correlation was found between clinical phenotype and specific genetic variants.
population_specificity: 234 patients from 212 families with ANO5-related muscle disease, contributed by 15 centers across 11 European countries.

study_goal: To evaluate the benefits and harms of exercise (including walking) plus standard care compared with standard care alone in adults with cancer receiving radiation therapy alone.
results_summary: Exercise, including walking, may reduce fatigue and improve physical performance in some cases, but the evidence is of low certainty. Effects on quality of life and psychosocial outcomes were minimal or unclear.
population_specificity: Adults with breast or prostate cancer receiving radiation therapy without adjuvant systemic treatment.
effective_dosage: Supervised exercise programs several times per week, including treadmill walking, warm-up, and cool-down (specific duration/frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of radiation therapy (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare cardiorespiratory responses between the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) and the 1-minute sit-to-stand test (1minSTS) in adults with advanced lung disease and to determine if the 6-minute walk distance (6MWD) could be estimated from the 1minSTS result.
results_summary: The 1minSTS resulted in less oxygen desaturation than the 6MWT and classified fewer participants as 'severe desaturators' during exertion. The study concluded that the 1minSTS is not a suitable substitute for the 6MWT in assessing desaturation severity.
population_specificity: Eighty adults (43 males) with advanced lung disease, mean age 64 years (SD 10), mean forced expiratory volume in 1 second of 1.65 L (SD 0.77).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 10-year survival rate and prognostic factors in Chinese CTD-PAH patients, comparing treatment and survival outcomes before and after 2015, and validating a four-strata model for predicting survival.
results_summary: The 10-year survival rate was 59.9%, with improvements in survival rates (1-year: 89.8% to 93.9%; 3-year: 80.1% to 86.5%) and increased use of combination therapies (PAH-targeted: 10.1% to 26.5%; binary: 14.8% to 35%). The four-strata model effectively predicted 10-year survival (C-index = 0.742).
population_specificity: Chinese patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with connective tissue disease (CTD-PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of non-surgical treatments with and without supervised exercise for pain intensity, symptom severity, functional impairment/disability, walking distance, and quality of life in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The study found that supervised exercise combined with non-surgical treatments led to reduced leg pain intensity and symptom severity, improved walking distance, and enhanced quality of life in the immediate term. Long-term results showed reduced functional disability/impairment and sustained improvements in walking distance and quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) (244 participants across three studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of traditional Chinese exercises (TCEs) on the rehabilitation of patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) using a meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 21 randomized controlled trials involving 1,665 patients showed that TCEs improved physiological outcomes, heart failure-related clinical symptoms, quality of life, and other recovery indicators in CHF patients, though the evidence was noted as insufficient with large heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine associations between BMI, physical activity program preferences, and related social cognitive theory variables in post-treatment breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that BMI was significantly correlated with exercise barriers interference, suggesting obesity may influence perceived obstacles to physical activity in breast cancer survivors. Other relationships between BMI, PA preferences, and social cognitive variables were analyzed but not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 320 post-treatment breast cancer survivors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of aerobic exercise, including walking, on physical function, cognition, and patient-reported measures of disease and fatigue impact in early multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that 48 weeks of supervised aerobic exercise, including walking, positively modified physical function (e.g., aerobic fitness and walking performance) but did not significantly affect cognitive function. Perception of disease and fatigue impact may also be modifiable by exercise in early MS.
population_specificity: Individuals with early multiple sclerosis (time since diagnosis <2 years, n=84).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) to the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex on distinct symptom domains across neuropsychiatric disorders, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found large effect sizes for craving reduction with repetitive TMS to the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, but no findings related to Walking were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with neuropsychiatric disorders (7905 participants, mean age 44.63 years, 52.35% male).
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (study focused on TMS, not Walking).
study_duration: Not mentioned (study focused on TMS, not Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare observational gait/functional movement analysis to electronic gait analysis in children with ALL/lymphoblastic lymphoma during and after treatment.
results_summary: Electronic gait parameters showed no differences compared to controls, while observational gait and functional movement analysis identified more deficits, with hopping being the most frequent and walking the least frequent noted deficit. Patient and parent-reported QoL scores were lower than the general population.
population_specificity: Children and young adults (2-27 years old) diagnosed with ALL/lymphoblastic lymphoma, either on or off therapy within 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a Nordic walking training program combined with education and usual care improves exercise tolerance and other health-related outcomes in asthma patients compared to education and usual care alone.
results_summary: The study expects Nordic walking combined with education and usual care to improve exercise tolerance and asthma-related outcomes, though final results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: 114 adults with asthma recruited in the sanitary area of A Coruña, Spain.
effective_dosage: Supervised Nordic walking sessions three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) and the treatment effects of particle repositioning maneuvers (PRM) on gait, falls, and fear of falling.
results_summary: People with BPPV walked slower and exhibited more sway during tandem walking and head rotations compared to controls. After PRM treatment, gait velocity during level walking improved significantly, falls and fear of falling decreased, but impairments during tandem walking and walking with head rotations did not improve.
population_specificity: Individuals with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the prognostic value of three physical frailty scales in ambulatory patients with heart failure, focusing on outcomes like death, hospitalization, and health-related quality of life.
results_summary: All three frailty scales were independently associated with increased risk of death or hospitalization and reduced health-related quality of life, with the Short Physical Performance Battery showing the strongest association with worsening SF-36 scores.
population_specificity: Ambulatory patients with heart failure (mean age 77.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore associations between visuospatial/executive function and activity performance (mobility, self-care, domestic life) and the outcome of gait training interventions long-term after stroke.
results_summary: Visuospatial/executive function was significantly associated with baseline activity performance and improved outcomes in conventional gait training, but not in robotic gait training. Patients with severe impairments may benefit more from robotic gait training.
population_specificity: 45 participants living with stroke affecting walking ability, 1-10 years post-stroke.
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cognitive-motor dual-task gait rehabilitation (DT GR) is more effective than single-task gait rehabilitation (ST GR) in improving gait, balance, cognitive performance, autonomy, disability, and quality of life in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that DT GR would lead to greater improvements in gait, balance, and cognitive outcomes compared to ST GR, with benefits expected in short, medium, and long-term recovery after stroke. The trial was designed as a multicenter, randomized controlled superiority study with a robust sample size.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different supervised exercise therapies on walking capacity in patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: Combined training showed comparable improvement in treadmill walking capacity to aerobic walking but with a larger effect size. Underwater training and aerobic walking also improved walking capacity, though combined training was the most promising modality.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included aerobic exercise, resistance training, combined training, and underwater exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining bodyweight support-T'ai Chi (BWS-TC) and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) has synergistic effects on improving motor function in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study proposes to evaluate the efficacy, acceptability, and safety of BWS-TC, tDCS, and their combination, with primary outcomes including motor function (Fugl-Meyer Assessment) and secondary outcomes covering balance, walking function, and brain structure/function. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with severe motor dysfunction and fear of falling.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two needle tip positions (inside vs. outside the pedicle) in pulsed radiofrequency treatment for herpes zoster-related pain.
results_summary: The study found that positioning the needle tip inside the pedicle (IP group) resulted in significantly better pain relief and improved quality of life at 30 and 90 days post-treatment compared to the outside position (OP group). Walking ability was one of the assessed activities of daily living, but specific results for walking were not highlighted separately.
population_specificity: 71 patients suffering from herpes zoster-related pain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (pulsed radiofrequency treatment parameters not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1, 7, 30, and 90 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exercise therapy on biomechanical loads (e.g., knee adduction moment) in patients with knee osteoarthritis and identify physical characteristics influencing these changes.
results_summary: Exercise therapy slightly increased biomechanical loads (e.g., knee adduction moment) but was associated with improved knee muscle strength and pain relief. The quality of evidence was low-to-moderate, suggesting a trade-off between symptom relief and biomechanical load reduction.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (average age: 63.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of BM-MSCs in improving left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) in patients with cardiomyopathy.
results_summary: BM-MSCs treatment significantly improved 6MWD by 27.86 m and LVEF by 6.37% compared to control groups, indicating effectiveness in managing heart failure.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiomyopathy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if postoperative physical activity (≥9 MET-h/wk, comparable to brisk walking) prevents or delays cancer recurrence in patients with stage III colon cancer.
results_summary: Physically active patients (≥9 MET-h/wk) had a lower risk of recurrence or death, with significant disease-free survival benefits in the first postoperative year (HR 0.68) and overall survival benefits in the first three years (HR 0.32). Physical activity appeared to prevent, rather than delay, cancer recurrence.
population_specificity: Patients with surgically resected stage III colon cancer (n=1696).
effective_dosage: ≥9 MET-h/wk (equivalent to 150 min/wk of brisk walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining translingual neurostimulation (TLNS) with physical therapy (PT) improves walking and balance in people with Multiple Sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study design evaluates the effects of PT + TLNS versus PT + Sham on gait and balance in MS patients, with outcomes measured at baseline, post-therapy (14 weeks), and follow-up (26 weeks). Results are pending as the abstract describes the study protocol rather than final findings.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-70 with gait and balance deficits due to relapsing-remitting or progressive MS, recruited from patient registries in Newfoundland & Labrador and Saskatchewan, Canada.
effective_dosage: Not specified (TLNS or sham device used during 14 weeks of PT).
study_duration: 14 weeks of PT, with follow-up at 26 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a machine learning model to predict medial tibiofemoral cartilage worsening over 2 years in individuals without advanced knee osteoarthritis and identify influential predictors.
results_summary: The model showed good performance (AUC 0.73) in predicting cartilage worsening, with baseline cartilage damage, higher Kellgren-Lawrence grade, greater pain during walking, higher lateral ground reaction force impulse, greater time spent lying, and lower vertical ground reaction force unloading rate associated with increased risk.
population_specificity: Individuals without advanced knee osteoarthritis from the Multicenter Osteoarthritis Study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions designed to reduce pedestrian distraction caused by mobile phone use while walking, particularly at intersections.
results_summary: The review found that existing interventions (e.g., in-ground lights, mobile apps) vary in focus and evaluation methods, with infrastructure-based interventions assessing behavioral change and app-based ones focusing on obstacle detection. The lack of a systematic evaluation approach and alignment with pedestrian needs limits their effectiveness.
population_specificity: Pedestrians using mobile phones while walking, particularly at intersections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel genetic variants in the GAN gene associated with giant axonal neuropathy and describe the clinical features, including walking difficulties, in affected patients.
results_summary: The study identified two novel variants in the GAN gene in Iranian families, with patients exhibiting walking difficulties, ataxic gait, and other typical GAN symptoms. Review of previous cases confirmed gait problems as a common clinical feature.
population_specificity: Three patients from two unrelated Iranian families with giant axonal neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of trunk training after stroke on activities of daily living, trunk function, arm-hand function, standing balance, leg function, walking ability, and quality of life.
results_summary: Trunk training showed positive effects on activities of daily living, trunk function, standing balance, walking ability, and quality of life, with varying levels of certainty. No significant difference was observed in serious adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults (18 years or older) with either ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Gamma Knife corpus callosotomy (GK-CC) as an alternative to microsurgical corpus callosotomy for patients with intractable epilepsy suffering from severe drop attacks.
results_summary: The study found that 68% of patients had improvement in seizure control, with 16% becoming completely seizure-free, while 31% showed no appreciable improvement. Transient mild complications occurred in 37% of patients, but no permanent complications were observed except for one patient with pre-existing cognitive and walking difficulties.
population_specificity: Patients with intractable epilepsy suffering from severe drop attacks (19 patients).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the effectiveness of leg exercises, including walking, on preserving bone mineral density and muscle cross-sectional area in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found that individuals with SCI who engaged in FES- and frame-supported leg exercises showed better improvements in muscle and bone health compared to those using frame-assisted exercises alone, particularly when initiated early (within 3 months post-injury) and performed for ≥30 minutes/day, ≥3 times/week for up to 24 months.
population_specificity: Persons with physical disability due to spinal cord injury (SCI).
study_duration: Up to 24 months or as long as desired/tolerable

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and effects of virtual reality-enhanced home rehabilitation on walking and other outcomes in children and adolescents with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that home-based virtual reality rehabilitation improved walking, along with upper extremity and gross motor function, balance, and participation. Meta-analyses indicated significant improvements in functional outcomes.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a physical activity intervention, including walking, could reduce burden and improve healthy lifestyle behavior in family caregivers of schizophrenia patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in caregiver burden and healthy lifestyle behavior scores in the intervention group compared to the control group, indicating the efficacy of the physical activity program.
population_specificity: Family caregivers of patients with schizophrenia.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of free walking per session, part of an 8-session program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multisite Hebbian stimulation could strengthen corticospinal-motoneuronal synapses and improve walking and arm function in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Participants receiving Hebbian stimulation showed greater improvements in walking speed, corticospinal function, grasping, and quality of life compared to sham stimulation, with benefits persisting 9 months post-therapy.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (n=31 total: 20 in randomized study, 11 in follow-up prospective study).
effective_dosage: 20 or 40 sessions of Hebbian stimulation (180 paired pulses per session) followed by exercise.
study_duration: 20 or 40 sessions (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining transspinal stimulation with robotic gait training maximizes motor recovery in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study anticipates that tonic transspinal stimulation strengthens corticomotoneuronal connectivity and enhances dynamic neuromodulation through posture-dependent neuroplasticity, potentially improving standing and walking abilities. The results suggest this combined intervention could be more effective than locomotor training alone.
population_specificity: 45 individuals with chronic spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: 30 Hz transspinal stimulation at the Thoracic 10 vertebral level for 30 minutes, followed by 30 minutes of robotic gait training, over 40 sessions.
study_duration: 40 sessions (specific duration per session not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of two different physical interventions (aerobic and postural) on sedentary behavior and clinical changes in people with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found improvements in sedentary behavior, quality of life, and some clinical measures (e.g., BMI, blood pressure) in both intervention groups, with functional capacity improving only in the postural intervention group. No changes were observed in flexibility or disease severity.
population_specificity: People with schizophrenia in regular outpatient care.
effective_dosage: Not specified (3-month exercise protocol, but exact walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effect of weight-bearing Liuzijue Qigong on cardiopulmonary function in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pulmonary function, diaphragm movement, and cardiac hemodynamic parameters after 4 weeks of weight-bearing Liuzijue Qigong exercise, including enhanced cardiac output, reduced vascular resistance, and better respiratory metrics.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 0.25 kg sandbags on each wrist, 30-minute sessions (2 consecutive cycles), 5 times a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a tango-based intervention for improving well-being, physical abilities, and quality of life in older adults with and without cognitive impairment living in nursing homes.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant improvement in quality of life, high intervention attendance (92%), and positive subjective well-being scores (4.5 ± 0.5 on a five-point scale) after each session. Physical abilities and functional capacities were also assessed, though specific results for walking performance were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 84.9 ± 6.7 years) living in nursing homes, with and without cognitive impairment (mean mini mental state examination score 14.5 ± 7.4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine factors associated with achieving clinically relevant pain reduction in people with knee or hip osteoarthritis after participating in a self-management program involving education and exercise.
results_summary: Younger age, lower BMI, higher education, absence of walking-impacting comorbidities, less frequent pain, and unwillingness to undergo surgery were associated with higher odds of pain reduction in knee and hip OA patients. Results were more consistent for knee OA than hip OA.
population_specificity: People with knee (n = 18,871) or hip (n = 7,767) osteoarthritis.
study_duration: Follow-up at 3 and 12 months after intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a rehabilitation program combined with pain management on multifaceted outcomes in older patients with acute vertebral compression fractures.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention.
population_specificity: Older adults with acute vertebral compression fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the current state of social prescribing in Canada, including its role in connecting participants to non-clinical supports like walking groups.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Walking's effects, only mentioning it as one of several community-based activities within social prescribing interventions.
population_specificity: Underserved populations in Canada.

study_goal: To determine the clinical efficacy of nutritional intervention combined with muscle exercise on sarcopenia patients with femoral fracture.
results_summary: The study found that nutritional intervention combined with muscle exercise improved sarcopenia symptoms and promoted fracture recovery in patients with sarcopenic femoral fractures, as evidenced by better functional independence and shorter hospital stays.
population_specificity: 100 sarcopenia patients with femoral fracture (50 in control group, 50 in research group).
study_duration: From January 2019 to January 2021 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether stable supportive footwear reduces hip pain during walking compared to flat flexible footwear in people with chronic hip pain consistent with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. The primary outcome will measure the 6-month change in average hip pain on walking.
population_specificity: Adults aged over 45 years with chronic hip pain consistent with osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Participants were advised to wear study shoes daily for a minimum of 6 hours each day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of home-based cardiac telerehabilitation (HBCTR) on physical function and quality of life in patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
results_summary: The study found that HBCTR significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness (measured by the six-minute walking test) and reduced certain cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., triglycerides and LDL cholesterol), but did not significantly affect quality of life or diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

study_goal: To determine whether statin medication affects the capacity to mobilize and oxidize fat during exercise in individuals with obesity, dyslipidemia, and metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that statins did not compromise the ability to mobilize and oxidize fat at rest or during prolonged, moderately intense exercise (equivalent to brisk walking). Fat oxidation rates during exercise were similar between statin and placebo conditions.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, dyslipidemia, and metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: Not specified (statin use or withdrawal was the intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal timing of exercise therapy (treadmill walking) to improve cardiorespiratory fitness in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in CRF improvement between concurrent and sequential exercise therapy relative to usual care. However, continuous exercise (≈32 weeks) was well-tolerated and significantly improved VO2peak compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Inactive women with breast cancer initiating (neo)adjuvant chemotherapy (n = 158).
effective_dosage: Treadmill walking three sessions/week, 20-50 min at 55%-100% of peak oxygen consumption (VO2peak).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of pharmacopuncture therapy (PPT) combined with conventional Korean Medicine treatment (CKMT) compared to CKMT alone for patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the treatment, as it describes a planned pilot trial rather than completed findings.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of an 8-week overground walking program with paretic lower limb loading on improving spatiotemporal gait parameters and motor function in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial comparing overground walking with and without paretic lower limb loading, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. Outcomes will assess gait parameters and motor function at baseline, 4, 8, and 20 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with mild to moderate disability recruited from two tertiary facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and effectiveness of a paclitaxel-coated balloon catheter for treating femoropopliteal atherosclerotic lesions in Chinese patients.
results_summary: The study found a low rate of major adverse events (0.6% at 30 days) and high primary patency (80.0% at 12 months), with significant clinical improvement (95.3% of patients). Walking distance improved by 60m at 12 months.
population_specificity: Chinese patients with Rutherford class 2-4 femoropopliteal atherosclerotic lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of the IPACK nerve block in combination with other regional nerve blocks for pain relief after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: IPACK supplementation significantly reduced rest pain scores at 8-12 hours post-surgery and was found to be effective and safe for early postoperative pain relief.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (1652 patients across 20 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how reducing cancer-related fatigue (CRF) through yoga influences CRF's interference with walking, physical activity (PA), and quality of life (QoL) in cancer survivors.
results_summary: Yoga significantly improved CRF's interference with walking, PA, and QoL, with 44%-53% of these improvements attributed to reductions in CRF. The effect size was -0.33 for all outcomes, indicating moderate but meaningful benefits.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (n=410) with insomnia 2 to 24 months posttreatment.

study_goal: To measure the effects of cerebral intermittent theta-burst stimulation combined with physiotherapy on lower extremity motor recovery in patients with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that intermittent theta-burst stimulation with physiotherapy significantly improved lower extremity motor recovery, walking speed, stride length, and functional ability compared to sham treatment. The intervention group showed greater improvements in all primary and secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with incomplete spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Daily intermittent theta-burst stimulation immediately before physiotherapy, 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise interventions, including walking, improve sleep quality in perimenopausal women.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise, including walking, effectively improved sleep quality and reduced insomnia symptoms in perimenopausal women, with a significant overall effect (SMD = -0.44, P < 0.00001). Walking was one of the interventions studied, but subgroup analysis highlighted fitness Qigong as the most effective.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking (other interventions: 3+ times/week, 30-60 min/session)
study_duration: Varied (10-12 weeks for most effective intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness, participation, and safety of individual training (IT) versus group training (GT) supervised exercise programs for women with postmenopausal osteoporosis (POP).
results_summary: Both IT and GT showed similar effectiveness, participation, and safety. Physical function and functional capacity improved in both groups, and weekly physical activity levels increased from moderate to intense.
population_specificity: 52 women with postmenopausal osteoporosis, without significant comorbidity, and no recent participation in structured exercise programs.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of a multicomponent progressive training program (MPTP) on functionality, quality of life (QoL), and motivation to exercise (EM) in older adults (OA) of a community.
results_summary: The experimental group (EG) showed improvements in functionality (SPPB, TUG, WWT, MD, FEV), QoL, and EM compared to the control group (CG). The MPTP was found to be safe and effective for community-dwelling older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 69.42 ± 6.01 years) from a community.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of school-based interventions, including those promoting active travel (walking and cycling), on children's exposure to environmental stressors and their health outcomes.
results_summary: Multi-component interventions to increase active travel (walking and cycling) showed effectiveness after three years, though overall study quality was rated as poor due to weak designs.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 in school settings.
study_duration: Up to three years for active travel interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare blink rates and interblink intervals during walking and other tasks to assess differences in spontaneous blinking behavior.
results_summary: Walking resulted in a higher blink rate (mean 31.3 ± 15.5 blinks/min) and shorter interblink interval (mean 1.9 ± 1.3 seconds) compared to reading tasks, with no significant difference from conversation. Changes in blinking occurred immediately upon task initiation.
population_specificity: 24 students (28.6 ± 6.3 years; 8 male, 16 female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of low-dose radiation therapy (LDRT) for patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA), specifically focusing on pain relief during walking.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported yet. The abstract outlines the methodology and objectives but does not provide findings on the efficacy or safety of LDRT for knee OA.
population_specificity: Patients with primary knee OA (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2-3) and baseline walking pain scores of 50-90 on a visual analogue scale.
effective_dosage: 0.3 Gy/6 fractions or 3 Gy/6 fractions of LDRT.
interactions: Concomitant use of analgesics was prohibited until the primary efficacy evaluation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the application of biomechanics tools to identify gait impairments and their clinical implications on rehabilitation in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that gait in PAD patients is impaired from the first steps and deteriorates further after claudication pain onset, pointing to impaired muscle function across ankle, knee, and hip joints during walking. Gait analysis helps understand PAD mechanisms and could aid earlier diagnosis, better treatment, and slower disease progression.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) experiencing intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between unemployment (a contributor to financial toxicity) and patient-reported outcomes in individuals with primary CNS tumors.
results_summary: The study found that unemployment due to a primary CNS tumor strongly correlated with high symptom burden, functional impairment, psychological distress, and reduced health-related quality of life. Financial toxicity from unemployment exacerbated physical, social, and cognitive challenges in this population.
population_specificity: 277 participants diagnosed with primary CNS tumors (57% male, 43% female; median age 45 years, range 18-74).
study_duration: Data collected between September 2016 and December 2019 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of pulmonary hypertension (PH) in patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) and identify predictors of PH, including the role of hypoxia and fibrotic patterns in HRCT chest.
results_summary: The study found that PH was prevalent in 28.33% of HP patients, with fibrotic patterns in HRCT chest and hypoxia being significant predictors. Patients with HP and PH exhibited more symptoms, fibrotic patterns, and significant desaturation after the six-minute walking test (6MWT).
population_specificity: 60 patients with established diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP), predominantly female (83.3%), with a mean age of 41.67 ± 13.4 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare disability progression in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis patients of Iraqi and northern European origin, focusing on walking-related disability (EDSS score ≥6.0).
results_summary: Patients of Iraqi origin progressed faster to moderate disability (EDSS 3.0-5.5) but not to severe walking-related disability (EDSS ≥6.0). Gene expression analysis suggested enhanced neurodegeneration pathways in Iraqi-origin patients.
population_specificity: 2396 Jewish patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (188 Iraqi-origin, 2207 northern European-origin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of remote-supported cardiac rehabilitation programs, including walking, on controlling traditional risk factors in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation after catheter ablation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in physical activity (measured by metabolic equivalents for walking) in intervention groups, with increases of 55.0% and 75.0% in groups 1 and 2, respectively, compared to a minimal 1.4% increase in the control group. Walking, as part of the rehabilitation program, contributed to better control of body weight, blood pressure, and cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Patients aged 35-79 years with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation after catheter ablation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking was part of a broader rehabilitation program).
study_duration: 3 months of remote support, with follow-up at 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of walking on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in people with cancer, comparing it to other exercise interventions and usual care.
results_summary: Walking showed a significant positive effect on HRQoL as measured by cancer-specific questionnaires (effect size: 0.39, 95%CI: 0.04-0.74). The study concluded that combined aerobic and resistance training was most effective, but walking also demonstrated meaningful benefits.
population_specificity: People with cancer (7435 participants across 93 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of supervised exercise prehabilitation programs, including walking, to enhance patient fitness and improve surgical outcomes before major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The study found that prehabilitation programs significantly improved 6-minute walking distance (+33 m) and peak oxygen uptake (+1.47 mL·kg), particularly when supervised sessions occurred more than once per week.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major abdominal surgery (1258 participants across 20 RCTs).
effective_dosage: More than one supervised session per week (specific walking duration/distance not detailed).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 10-mg of triamcinolone acetonide (TA) is non-inferior to 40-mg TA for pain treatment in symptomatic knee osteoarthritis patients at week 12.
results_summary: The study found that 10-mg TA was non-inferior to 40-mg TA in improving pain, with both doses significantly enhancing pain and quality of life by week 12. No significant differences were observed between the two dosage groups in pain reduction or quality of life improvement.
population_specificity: 84 symptomatic knee osteoarthritis patients.
effective_dosage: 10-mg or 40-mg triamcinolone acetonide (TA), injected once at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare outcomes between intramedullary nailing (IMN) and locked lateral plating (LLP) for treating extraarticular proximal tibial fractures, focusing on functional recovery and walking ability.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in functional outcomes, walking ability, or complications between IMN and LLP groups. Both groups showed continued improvement over 12 months but remained impaired at the one-year mark.
population_specificity: 108 patients with extraarticular proximal tibial fractures, followed for 12 months (99 completed follow-up).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical interventions, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 2-year maintenance training (MT) exergaming and detraining (DT) on clinical-motor symptoms in subacute ischemic stroke patients.
results_summary: Maintenance training (MT) retained initial rehabilitation-induced gains, particularly in walking capacity, while detraining (DT) modestly reduced these improvements. MT further increased improvements in selected variables but not universally across all outcomes.
population_specificity: Subacute ischemic stroke patients (n=558).
effective_dosage: MT exergaming consisted of once a day, 3 times per week for 2 years; initial rehabilitation involved high-intensity exergaming twice or once a day, 5 times per week for 5 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess patient-reported outcomes and survival after surgical and nonsurgical treatment of malignant bowel obstruction, including interference with walking.
results_summary: The study found that surgical treatment was associated with greater symptom interference in general activities and walking, with a composite score effect size of -0.37, but also improved survival compared to nonsurgical treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced malignancy and malignant bowel obstruction undergoing surgical consultation at a tertiary cancer center.
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed at enrollment and 7 other time points over 90 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the personal experience of walking among adults with mobility-impairing health conditions and propose a conceptual framework of walking experience.
results_summary: The study identified seven themes describing the walking experience, which were consistent across various health conditions, and proposed a novel conceptual framework to represent this multi-faceted and dynamic experience.
population_specificity: Adults with mobility-impairing health conditions (e.g., Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hip fracture, heart failure, frailty, sarcopenia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of adductor canal block (ACB) versus anterior local infiltration analgesia (LIA) in reducing morphine consumption and pain after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: No significant difference in 48-hour morphine consumption was found between ACB and anterior LIA groups. Pain scores were slightly better with anterior LIA, but the difference was not clinically relevant.
population_specificity: 98 patients undergoing primary total knee arthroplasty under spinal anesthesia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ACB and LIA with local anesthetic or saline sham).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify appropriate clinical measures for evaluating dual-task gait in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The review identified 16 studies using various dual-task tests (e.g., cognitive timed up and go, walking while talking) but concluded there is a lack of valid and reliable clinical measures for dual-task gait evaluation in T2DM.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of different frequencies and durations of sedentary breaks involving light-intensity walking on cardiometabolic risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that interrupting sedentary time with light-intensity walking every 30 minutes for 5 minutes significantly improved glycemic responses, while all tested doses significantly reduced systolic blood pressure. The largest blood pressure reductions occurred with breaks every 60 minutes for 1 minute and every 30 minutes for 5 minutes.
population_specificity: Middle- and older-age adults (n = 11)
effective_dosage: Every 30 minutes for 1 minute, every 30 minutes for 5 minutes, every 60 minutes for 1 minute, and every 60 minutes for 5 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether whole-body vibration training improves balance and gait ability in older hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in balance or gait ability from whole-body vibration training, with no differences in the Timed Up and Go test, single-leg stand test, or 30-second chair stand test between the intervention and control groups. No musculoskeletal adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Older hemodialysis patients (aged ≥65 years) without dementia or significant walking difficulties.
effective_dosage: 3 minutes, thrice a week on dialysis days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-meal or post-meal walking has a greater impact on reducing postprandial glucose excursions in individuals with and without type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Post-meal walking significantly reduced postprandial glucose excursions compared to pre-meal walking and inactive control, while pre-meal walking showed no significant benefit. The timing between meal and exercise moderated glucose excursions, with earlier post-meal walking being more effective.
population_specificity: 116 participants (47 with type 2 diabetes, 69 without).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of early mobilization versus traditional plaster cast immobilization after total ankle replacement using a 3-component cementless, unconstrained, mobile-bearing prosthesis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in functional, mobility, quality-of-life, pain relief, or satisfaction outcomes between early mobilization and plaster cast groups at 2 years post-surgery, suggesting early mobilization is a safe and reliable recovery method. Bone mineral density changes were better in the early mobilization group, though differences existed preoperatively.
population_specificity: 20 patients (10 per group) who underwent total ankle replacement with a specific prosthesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify physical function measures associated with future falls in older adults to improve fall prediction models.
results_summary: The study found that fall history, SPPB (Short Physical Performance Battery), and postural stability on foam were significantly associated with future falls in older adults, with postural stability on foam remaining significant after adjusting for fall history.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of catheter ablation (CA) versus medical therapy (MT) in improving functional capacity (measured by 6-minute walking test) and clinical outcomes in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and heart failure (HF).
results_summary: The study found that CA was associated with a significant improvement in the 6-minute walking test (6MWT) compared to MT, with a mean difference of 13.70 meters. CA also showed better outcomes in reducing hospitalizations and improving left ventricle ejection fraction (LVEF).
population_specificity: Patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and heart failure (HF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 12 sessions of overground robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) combined with conventional training improves walking independence and quality of life in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The RAGT group showed significant improvements in walking independence (FAC, timed-up-and-go, 10-m walk test) and quality of life (EQ-5D) compared to the control group, while both groups improved in balance and daily living activities.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke survivors (n=17, intervention n=9, control n=8).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 3 times/week for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions (face-to-face or digital) on exercise capacity, quality of life, and symptoms like breathlessness and fatigue in adults with persistent COVID-19 symptoms.
results_summary: The study protocol compares rehabilitation interventions to usual care, with primary outcomes measured by the Incremental Shuttle Walking Test and secondary outcomes including function, strength, and symptom assessment. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Adults hospitalized with COVID-19 experiencing persistent symptoms such as fatigue, breathlessness, and brain fog.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention combines symptom-titrated exercise therapy, symptom management, and education).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pulmonary physiotherapy (PPT), including walking (3MWT), in hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.
results_summary: PPT improved pO2, SpO2, and walking distance (3MWT) but did not significantly affect pCO2. Mortality risks were reduced at one and three months, though not statistically significant. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Hospitalized, non-intubated patients (18-75 years) with severe COVID-19 pneumonia and SpO2 ≤90% in free-air breathing.
effective_dosage: Six sessions of PPT, including breathing exercises and airway clearance techniques.
study_duration: Duration of six PPT sessions (exact timeframe not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise training, including brisk walking, could achieve clinically meaningful improvement in MRI-measured liver fat in adults with NAFLD.
results_summary: Exercise training, including brisk walking at ≥750 MET-min/week (e.g., 150 min/week), was 3.5 times more likely to achieve a ≥30% reduction in liver fat compared to no exercise, independent of weight loss. Lesser exercise doses did not show significant treatment response.
population_specificity: Adults with NAFLD (mean age 53.3 years, BMI 31.1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the availability and characteristics of pulmonary rehabilitation programs in Chile, including the role of walking as part of these programs.
results_summary: Walking was included as a component of pulmonary rehabilitation programs, which were mainly outpatient and non-personalized. The programs showed moderate completion rates (40-80%) and used assessments like the six-minute walking test to evaluate outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic respiratory conditions, primarily Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), in family health centers and hospitals in Chile.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between changes in physical activity (specifically walking and moderate-to-vigorous-intensity activity) and changes in body weight in an underserved population participating in a weight loss program.
results_summary: Greater increases in walking and moderate-to-vigorous-intensity activity were associated with greater percent reductions in body weight, with the highest tertile of walking change showing a mean weight loss of -7.3%. The intervention resulted in clinically significant weight loss, consistent with findings in non-underserved populations.
population_specificity: Underserved population in Louisiana (402 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and functional gait improvements of ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) and functional electrical stimulation (FES) devices for persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) experiencing foot-drop.
results_summary: The review found variability in study designs, making direct comparisons between AFO and FES unreliable, but provided evidence statements on device effects and recommendations for future research. Clinicians can use the insights to prescribe more customized treatments.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) experiencing foot-drop.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early gait training using Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) improves walking ability and independence compared to conventional physical therapy (CPT) in stroke patients with severe walking disability.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in primary outcomes (walking ability and independence) between HAL and CPT groups. However, the HAL group showed a decreasing trend in apathy scores, while the CPT group showed a slight increase.
population_specificity: Patients with first-ever stroke and severe walking disability, median age 68 years.
study_duration: From baseline to 3 months after initiation of gait training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a home-based pulmonary rehabilitation program with and without telecoaching, including regular walking, on health-related outcomes in COVID-19 survivors.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in six-minute walk distance and other health metrics, but the telecoaching group had greater reductions in dyspnea and fatigue and better social functioning scores.
population_specificity: COVID-19 survivors who completed medical treatment (n = 42).

study_goal: To determine the feasibility of a randomized controlled trial examining outdoor walking's effects on knee osteoarthritis clinical outcomes and MRI structural changes.
results_summary: The walking group showed clinically important improvements in symptoms (e.g., reduced knee pain) compared to usual care, with 70% program adherence and 70.8% retention. The study identified recruitment challenges but supported the feasibility of a full-scale RCT.
population_specificity: Adults with knee osteoarthritis (mean age 66 years, 60% female).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of gait training on a sandy beach versus firm ground on walking ability and balance in patients with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Gait training on a sandy beach significantly improved 10-minute walk test and Berg Balance Scale scores, as well as cadence and gait velocity, compared to firm ground. No significant differences were found in psychological parameters (BDI and STAI) between groups, and no adverse events occurred.
population_specificity: 28 patients with chronic stroke.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 2 sessions every day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of walking with huffing against other airway clearance techniques on sputum expectoration and other health outcomes in adults hospitalized with an acute exacerbation of bronchiectasis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for walking with huffing, but the study aims to evaluate its effectiveness in sputum expectoration, health-related quality of life, and exercise tolerance during and after hospitalization.
population_specificity: Adults hospitalized with an acute exacerbation of bronchiectasis.
study_duration: Interventions were administered during inpatient stay (day 2 and day 6 of admission) and outcomes were monitored for six months post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the best gait rehabilitation method for improving velocity, distance, and WISCI in incomplete spinal cord injury patients.
results_summary: Acute-phase robotic-assisted gait training significantly improved velocity, distance, and WISCI compared to conventional physical therapy. Functional electrical stimulation had the highest probability of being the best intervention for velocity and distance.
population_specificity: Incomplete spinal cord injury patients (mean age 43.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if metformin improves functional status, retards PAD progression, and reduces systemic inflammation in non-diabetic patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported yet. The primary outcome will assess maximum walking distance after 180 days of metformin or placebo treatment.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic Veterans with intermittent claudication due to peripheral artery disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the characteristics and effectiveness of blended face-to-face and eHealth interventions in promoting physical activity (including walking), diet, and weight-related outcomes among adults.
results_summary: The study found that blended interventions significantly increased walking steps and total physical activity levels, but had no effect on moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA). Additionally, the interventions improved diet quality and reduced energy intake, weight, BMI, and waist circumference.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of music-based interventions on motor and non-motor outcomes in individuals with Parkinson’s disease, particularly focusing on walking velocity, stride length, and mobility.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that music-based interventions significantly improved walking velocity, stride length, and mobility in individuals with Parkinson’s disease, but showed no significant effects on cadence, cognitive flexibility, inhibition, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson’s disease (417 participants across 13 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a remotely-delivered, culturally-tailored exercise training program on walking dysfunction, symptoms, and health-related quality of life among African-Americans with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study will examine the effects of aerobic and resistance exercise training compared to stretching and flexibility, focusing on walking dysfunction as the primary outcome, with secondary outcomes including fatigue, depression, anxiety, and HRQOL, and tertiary outcomes like exercise behavior and mediator variables. Results are pending as the study is proposed, not completed.
population_specificity: African-Americans with multiple sclerosis (n=100)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of aerobic exercise, specifically walking, in managing fatigue among cancer patients, particularly those with advanced or metastatic disease.
results_summary: The study found that walking, as a form of aerobic exercise, has benefits in reducing fatigue in cancer patients, especially those with earlier-stage disease or undergoing active treatment. The evidence for walking is stronger compared to other interventions like medications, though the mechanisms may differ in advanced disease.
population_specificity: Cancer patients, particularly those with locally advanced or metastatic incurable disease, as well as earlier-stage patients and cancer survivors.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine assessments (clinical outcome measures and gait parameters) associated with fall risk in older adults using lower-limb prostheses to inform an evidence-based clinical protocol.
results_summary: The majority of articles found no single clinical outcome measure or gait parameter effectively identified fall risks in this population. Only six articles identified clinical outcome measures and two identified gait parameters with statistically significant associations with falls.
population_specificity: Older adults using transtibial or transfemoral prostheses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-operative exercise, including walking (aerobic exercises), improves physical performance and reduces post-operative complications in older individuals with low pre-operative physical capacity scheduled for colorectal cancer surgery.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that pre-operative exercise, including walking, will enhance physical function and reduce post-operative complications, but final efficacy results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Older individuals with low pre-operative physical capacity scheduled for colorectal cancer surgery.
effective_dosage: Minimum of 6 supervised physiotherapist sessions, complemented with unsupervised exercise sessions (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Pre-operative period (timeframe not explicitly stated, but within 14-28 days from suspicion to surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of cognitive intervention (flanker task) and physical exercise (including walking) on mobility in older adults, and determine the dosage equivalence between cognitive and physical training for similar mobility improvements.
results_summary: Both cognitive and physical exercise interventions improved mobility similarly, though the physical exercise group showed better performance in the 30-s chair-stand test and single-leg balance. A 22-week cognitive intervention (1,980 min total) achieved comparable mobility improvements to mild-to-moderate physical exercise (1,320 min of functional training plus 1,980 min of daily activities).
population_specificity: 232 older adults (mean age 66.16 ± 7.08, 74.3% female).
effective_dosage: Physical exercise included 30 min of muscle and balance training twice a week, plus 30 min of daily walking and housework 2-4 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term impacts of hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance issues in cancer survivors treated with platinum-based chemotherapy, including effects on walking.
results_summary: Poor balance was found to interfere with walking and increase the risk of falls among cancer survivors treated with platinum-based chemotherapy.
population_specificity: People living with and beyond cancer (LWBC) treated with platinum-based chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and clinical outcomes of primary stenting plus best medical treatment (BMT) versus BMT alone in patients with intermittent claudication caused by isolated superficial femoral artery lesions.
results_summary: Primary stenting initially improved HRQoL and walking ability at 36 months, but these benefits were not sustained at 60 months. No significant differences were found in disease progression, amputation rates, or mortality between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication due to isolated superficial femoral artery lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively describe the type, quantity, and daily variation of physical activity, including walking, among mechanically ventilated ICU patients.
results_summary: Mechanically ventilated ICU patients spent only 1 hour per day standing, moving, walking, or bicycling, with activity peaks at 9:00 and 18:00, likely linked to nurse- or physiotherapy-initiated activities. The study concluded that these patients were primarily sedentary, highlighting a need for improved clinical routines to promote active mobilization.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated patients in mixed medical/surgical ICUs (n=39).
study_duration: Duration of ICU stay (not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effects of crocin supplementation on serum concentrations of IL-6 and TNF-α in the context of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multi-component interventions, including aerobic exercise (stepping) and diet, improved physical fitness and vascular function in pre-frail older women.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic exercise combined with diet significantly improved right grip strength, short physical performance battery scores, 6-minute walking distance, and flow-mediated dilation. Blood pressure and pulse wave velocity remained unchanged, while high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol levels increased in all intervention groups.
population_specificity: Pre-frail older women aged ≥ 65 years (mean age 81.5 ± 4.3 years).
effective_dosage: 45 minutes of stepping exercise at 50-70% of maximal heart rate, 3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term clinical outcomes and return to sports between arthroscopic all-inside and open anatomic reconstruction for chronic lateral ankle instability patients.
results_summary: The arthroscopic group showed significantly earlier return to full weightbearing walking, jogging, and recreational sports, with better functional scores and less pain at 3-6 months post-surgery, though both techniques achieved similar outcomes by 24 months.
population_specificity: 57 patients with chronic lateral ankle instability (CLAI).

study_goal: To investigate whether functional electrical stimulation cycling (FES-C) training combined with conventional physical therapy improves gait, muscle strength, gross motor function, and energy expenditure in children with spastic diplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The FES-C group showed greater improvements in functional muscle strength, gross motor function, and energy expenditure compared to conventional physical therapy alone, both after training and at follow-up.
population_specificity: Ambulatory children with spastic diplegic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate donor site comorbidity (specifically hip-related issues) following deep circumflex iliac artery (DCIA) graft harvesting using CAD/CAM techniques.
results_summary: The study found that despite advanced CAD/CAM planning, donor site morbidity remains an issue after iliac graft harvesting. Smaller graft volumes and minimal skin incisions may help reduce postoperative symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent DCIA graft harvesting using CAD/CAM techniques (n=15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in patient status and treatment outcomes for metastatic spinal tumors, including walking capacity due to lower paralysis, over a decade.
results_summary: The study found that non-ambulatory patients during consultation decreased significantly in the late group (28% vs. 16%), but postoperative lower function improvement remained limited in about half of the patients.
population_specificity: 186 patients (122 men, 64 women; mean age 67.6 years) diagnosed and treated for metastatic spinal tumors between 2009-2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current literature on Functional Gait Disorders (FGD) to understand their multidimensional nature, phenotypes, and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: FGD is disabling and presents with various phenotypes, including knee buckling and excessive slowness. Multidisciplinary rehabilitation has shown short and long-term improvements in walking ability, though optimal treatment elements remain undetermined.
population_specificity: Individuals with Functional Gait Disorders (FGD), a subset of motor-Functional Neurological Disorders (motor-FND).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of lateral-wedge insoles versus ordinary insoles on plantar pressure and clinical outcomes in patients with knee osteoarthritis during walking.
results_summary: The study found that ordinary insoles led to significant improvements in WOMAC function and total scores, but also increased transverse width of the center of pressure and partial foot pressure on the forefoot and heel. Significant group-by-time interactions were observed for partial foot pressure in the forefoot.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-frequency spinal cord stimulation (SCS) is more effective than low-frequency SCS for pain relief and functional improvement in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).
results_summary: High-frequency SCS provided significantly better pain relief, quality of life, and functional performance (measured by WIQ) compared to low-frequency SCS at 3 and 12 months, though no significant difference was found in walking speed or distance. Tissue perfusion did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: 50 patients (84% men, median age 66.5 years) with chronic limb-threatening ischemia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (spinal cord stimulation frequencies: 1 kHz for HF-SCS vs. low-frequency SCS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether forest therapy, including walking, reduces blood pressure and stress in urban residents compared to urban controls.
results_summary: Forest therapy significantly reduced systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, and salivary cortisol concentration, with greater effects observed in older participants and those with higher baseline levels. Longer-term programs (≥20 min) showed greater reductions, and walking had similar effects to seated viewing or multi-session programs.
population_specificity: Urban residents at higher risk of hypertension and psychological stress.
effective_dosage: Not specified (programs included seated viewing, walking, or multi-session activities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize literature on using machine learning to identify gait-related changes and determine functional recovery status in patients after knee surgery.
results_summary: The study found an increase in sophisticated machine learning techniques that provide robust decision-making support for personalized post-treatment interventions in knee-surgery patients, based on gait data. Six out of 405 reviewed articles met inclusion criteria and demonstrated the potential of these methods.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from knee surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nocturnal hemodialysis (NHD) improves physical performance (including walking) and protein-energy wasting (PEW) compared to conventional hemodialysis (CHD) in end-stage kidney disease patients.
results_summary: NHD did not significantly improve the short physical performance battery (SPPB) score compared to CHD, but it did improve walking distance (6MWT), self-reported physical component score (PCS), and subjective global assessment (SGA) after one year. No changes were observed in other physical performance or PEW parameters.
population_specificity: End-stage kidney disease patients (mean age 55 ± 15.3) undergoing hemodialysis.
effective_dosage: NHD (2–3 times/week for 7–8 hours) vs. CHD (2–4 times/week for 3–5 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-intensity exercise (HIE) on lower limb function and activities of daily living in acute and subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study examined outcomes such as lower limb function, Barthel index, 6 min walk test, gait speed, and Berg balance scale, but specific results regarding Walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Acute and subacute stroke patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIE defined as achieving at least 60% of heart rate reserve or VO₂).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) should be recommended as a prerequisite for in-utero repair of open neural tube defects (ONTD) and to compare outcomes between cases with normal CMA and those with reportable copy-number variants (CNVs).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in motor function at birth, 12 months, or walking status at 30 months between cases with normal CMA and those with reportable CNVs, suggesting that CMA results should not a priori affect eligibility for in-utero repair.
population_specificity: Pregnancies complicated by ONTD that underwent in-utero repair at a single tertiary center.
study_duration: Follow-up until 30 months of age for walking status.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of multi-task training versus single-task training and a control group on motor and cognitive performance in People with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS) without clinical disability.
results_summary: Multi-task training improved single cognitive and motor task performances and reduced cognitive Dual-Task Costs (DTCs) but did not significantly change motor DTCs. The MTTG showed better mental tracking DTC during walking compared to the STTG, and changes in postural and walking DTCs were linked to single-motor task performance improvements.
population_specificity: People with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS) without clinical disability (n=42).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of catheter-directed thrombolysis (CDT) in patients with Rutherford I acute lower limb ischemia (ALI), including functional outcomes like pain-free walking distance.
results_summary: The study found high angiographic success (80%) and 30-day freedom from amputation (98%) with CDT, but long-term outcomes were poor, with low patency rates (48% at one year) and substantial risk of major amputation. No data on walking distance was available.
population_specificity: Patients with Rutherford I acute lower limb ischemia (ALI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the factors affecting backward walking in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: The study found that backward walking ability improved with better forward walking function but was unaffected by proprioception, trunk control, and muscle strength. Significant differences were observed in spasticity and functional assessments between GMFCS levels I and II.
population_specificity: 30 children with CP (mean age 10.43 ± 2.76 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether GLP-1RAs improve heart failure prognosis and cardiac function, including effects on walking capacity measured by the six-minute walking test.
results_summary: GLP-1RAs significantly improved six-minute walking test distances and left ventricular diastolic function but did not reduce heart failure hospitalizations or improve other key cardiac markers.
population_specificity: Patients with or without diabetes and a history of heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if muscle strain measured by speckle tracking ultrasonography could serve as a useful quantitative measure of muscle function in patients with multiple sclerosis, compared to validated performance measures.
results_summary: The study found no significant correlations between muscle strain and gold standard performance measures for upper or lower extremity function, indicating that speckle tracking ultrasonography may not be valid for evaluating muscle function in multiple sclerosis. Performance measures like the 2-minute walking test and Six Spot Step Test showed fair to strong correlations with the gold standards.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis recruited from a hospital outpatient MS clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of exergaming (which includes walking-related activities) on restless legs syndrome (RLS) severity, walking capacity, and other related symptoms in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS).
