results_summary: The study found that exergaming improved RLS severity, walking capacity, balance, and sleep quality in persons with MS and RLS, with effects persisting at an 8-week follow-up. In persons with MS without RLS, exergaming improved gait and balance, but these improvements were not sustained at follow-up.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS), both with and without restless legs syndrome (RLS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the newer Journey II BCS total knee replacement design produced superior patient-reported and biomechanical outcomes compared to the older Genesis II design.
results_summary: The study found no difference in the primary outcome (Oxford Knee Score) between the two groups. However, the Genesis II group showed significantly better walking range-of-movement, higher peak knee flexion angular velocity during walking, and better postural control than the Journey II BCS group.
population_specificity: 80 participants undergoing single-stage total knee replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of BMI on clinical outcomes, including walking ability, following fusion surgery for osteoporotic vertebral fractures.
results_summary: The study found that patients with low BMI had significantly worse outcomes in walking ability and leg pain improvement compared to those with normal or high BMI. High BMI patients showed equivalent or slightly better results in pain and ADL improvements compared to normal BMI patients.
population_specificity: 237 osteoporotic vertebral fracture patients (mean age 74.3 years; 48 men, 189 women) with neurological symptoms who underwent spinal fusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prolonged experimental neck pain affects gait kinematics during walking and whether movement adaptations occur shortly after pain onset.
results_summary: The study found that walking while reading on a smartphone altered gait kinematics (shorter stride lengths and reduced range of motion in trunk, hip, knee, and ankle) compared to normal walking, but mild neck muscle pain did not cause significant changes.
population_specificity: Forty healthy participants.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was injections of nerve-growth-factor or isotonic saline, not a walking dosage).
study_duration: Assessments were conducted on days 0, 4, and 15.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect and optimal parameters of community-based exercise (including walking) on motor symptoms in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that community-based exercise, including Nordic walking, may benefit motor function in Parkinson's disease patients, with tango and tai chi being the most common modalities and a prescription of 60 minutes twice a week being the most frequent.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dual-task (DT) training on gait performance and cognitive function in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) and identify factors influencing these effects.
results_summary: DT training improved DT gait speed, step and stride length, attention, and executive function in PD patients, with moderate-quality evidence. The benefits on step and stride length were greater in participants with slower initial single-task gait speed.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of side-alternating vibration therapy (VT) protocols varying in frequency and treatment duration on mobility, gross motor function, body composition, muscle function, and quality of life in children with mild-to-moderate cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: Side-alternating VT significantly improved 6-minute walk test performance, gross motor function (standing, walking, running, jumping), spine bone mineral density, muscle function, and quality of life, with no differences between 20 Hz and 25 Hz frequencies. Long-term (20-week) VT showed more pronounced benefits than short-term (12-week) VT.
population_specificity: Children aged 6.0 to 12.6 years with mild-to-moderate cerebral palsy.
effective_dosage: 9 minutes per session, 4 days per week at either 20 Hz or 25 Hz frequency.
study_duration: 20 weeks (12-week VT followed by an additional 8-week VT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between sit-to-stand (STS) muscle power and functional outcomes in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) before and after supervised exercise training (SET).
results_summary: The study found that SET significantly improved STS muscle power, maximum treadmill walking distance, functional performance tests, and quality of life in PAD patients. Greater baseline STS muscle power was associated with better functional performance and quality of life, and larger improvements in STS muscle power post-SET correlated with greater functional gains.
population_specificity: Patients with Fontaine stage II peripheral artery disease (mean age 63.1 ± 12.1 years, 67% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 6-week rehabilitation program combining education and exercises on walking capacity in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis causing neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The study will assess walking capacity, pain intensity, disability, self-efficacy, physical activity, anxiety, depression, gait pattern, balance, and perceived change, but results are not yet reported as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis causing neurogenic claudication.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program includes standardized education and specific exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resistance training (RT) and whey protein supplementation (WPS) on 6-minute walking distance, muscle status, cardiac function, and quality of life in elderly HFpEF patients with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study will assess changes in 6-minute walking distance (primary outcome) and secondary outcomes like muscle status, cardiac function, and quality of life after 12 weeks of RT with or without WPS, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily WPS mentioned but no dosage details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-month exercise intervention, including walking, could improve hippocampal volume, cortical thickness, grey matter volume, and verbal memory in physically inactive breast cancer patients with cognitive problems.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of the exercise intervention on brain volume measures overall. However, in highly fatigued patients, a reduction in hippocampal volume was observed, which was associated with improved memory functioning.
population_specificity: Chemotherapy-exposed breast cancer patients (stage I-III, 2-4 years post-diagnosis) with cognitive problems.
effective_dosage: 2x1 hours/week of supervised aerobic and strength training and 2x1 hours/week Nordic or power walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of robot-assisted gait therapy (RAGT) on gait, balance, and functional independence in children with cerebral palsy, compared to conventional therapy or treadmill therapy.
results_summary: RAGT showed better results than conventional therapy in improving gait speed, walking distance, and walking, running, and jumping ability post-intervention, but no differences were found between RAGT and treadmill therapy or conventional therapy for other variables.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness and neurological mechanisms of combining robot motor assistance and neural circuit-based VR training for lower extremity rehabilitation in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: The study designed a rehabilitation system combining robot assistance with VR training, targeting muscle strength, posture control, balance, and walking. Outcomes will be measured using Fugl-Meyer assessment, Berg Balance Scale, Modified Ashworth Scale, and functional MRI, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 40 patients with lower extremity hemiparesis after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the momentary emotional effects of different scales and types of street-level urban green spaces (UGS) on tourists walking in an unfamiliar environment.
results_summary: The study found that large-scale green vegetation interventions in urban streets improved tourists' momentary emotional experiences, with cultural and leisure walking streets showing the largest positive impact compared to traffic lanes and commercial pedestrian streets.
population_specificity: 299 potential tourists who had never visited Xi'an.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intravenous or oral iron supplementation was more effective in improving physical fitness, measured by 6-minute walking distance, in anemic children with inflammatory bowel disease.
results_summary: A single IV dose of ferric carboxymaltose showed superior improvement in walking distance at 1 month compared to oral ferrous fumarate, but no differences were observed at 3 and 6 months. Hemoglobin levels increased comparably in both groups over time.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-18 with inflammatory bowel disease and anemia (hemoglobin z-score < -2).
effective_dosage: Single IV dose of ferric carboxymaltose or 12 weeks of oral ferrous fumarate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize findings from systematic reviews on urban interventions that promote physical activity, including walking.
results_summary: The study found positive effects of urban interventions on physical activity, particularly through park renovations, improved walking and cycling environments, and multi-component initiatives for active travel. The findings suggest that modifying the urban environment can effectively promote walking and other physical activities.
population_specificity: Not specified (umbrella review of systematic reviews)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate a non-invasive risk assessment strategy for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) using three variables, including 6-minute walking distance, and to confirm the importance of achieving a low-risk profile as a treatment goal.
results_summary: The study found that early achievement of a low-risk profile, assessed partly by 6-minute walking distance, was associated with significantly better survival and event-free survival rates compared to intermediate or high-risk groups. Low-risk patients had 100% survival at five years, while intermediate-risk patients showed declining survival rates over time.
population_specificity: 92 incident PAH patients (mean age 47, 77% female, 53% idiopathic PAH) from a Latin American cohort.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 3.11 years, with early follow-up at 9.5 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the relationship between health literacy (HL) and activities of daily living (ADL) in patients participating in cardiac rehabilitation, focusing on walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that patients with low HL had significantly lower motor and cognitive Functional Independence Measure (FIM) scores, indicating poorer ADL performance. Functional HL showed a stronger correlation with FIM scores than other HL subclasses.
population_specificity: Cardiac rehabilitation patients (median age 71.0 years, 76.9% male) without probable dementia or difficulty walking alone.
study_duration: Data collected from October 2020 to December 2021 (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of public transport use incentives on transport-related physical activity (including walking) in Tasmania, Australia.
results_summary: The intervention showed high acceptability and feasibility, with 90% of participants finding bus trip incentives helpful and 59% reporting increased motivation to use public transport. However, social and systemic barriers made meeting bus trip targets challenging for many participants.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-80 in Tasmania, Australia, with over-representation of females (69%) and those with tertiary education (55%).
effective_dosage: 16 weeks of bus trip credits for achieving weekly public transport use targets, supported by weekly text messages.

study_goal: To determine if the effects of exercise-based cancer rehabilitation, including walking, on physical functioning, activity, and participation are maintained 6 to 12 months post-intervention.
results_summary: Exercise-based rehabilitation, including walking, improved physical activity and other health outcomes in cancer survivors, with benefits maintained after rehabilitation completion.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (2974 participants across 19 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of exoskeleton-assisted Body Weight Supported Treadmill Training (BWSTT) on gait function in patients with chronic stroke and summarize intervention protocols and device types.
results_summary: The review found that exoskeleton-assisted BWSTT improved gait function in 10 of 11 studies, with two studies showing enhanced efficacy when combined with other therapies. However, no significant difference was observed compared to therapist-assisted BWSTT.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic stroke (onset ≥ 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality and applicability of clinical practice guidelines for knee osteoarthritis rehabilitation, including recommendations for walking and other interventions.
results_summary: The study found that gait/walking aids were recommended in 7 out of 24 guidelines for knee OA rehabilitation, indicating moderate support for walking as part of treatment. The overall quality of guidelines was good, but applicability was slightly poor.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of l-arginine in improving motor function and reducing inflammatory markers in patients with HTLV-1-associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP).
results_summary: The study found that l-arginine improved walking speed (10MWT) and mobility (TUGT) by Day 14, along with reduced CSF inflammatory markers, though the primary endpoint at Day 7 was not statistically significant. Adverse events were mild and infrequent.
population_specificity: 20 patients (65% female, mean age 67.8 years) diagnosed with HAM/TSP.
study_duration: 1 week of intervention, with follow-up for 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency and safety of Baofei Granules (BFGs) in treating COPD patients with lung and spleen qi deficiency syndrome.
results_summary: The study did not provide specific results regarding Walking, as it focused on BFGs for COPD management.
population_specificity: 216 stable COPD patients with lung and spleen qi deficiency syndrome.
effective_dosage: 10g BFGs or placebo three times per day.
study_duration: 52-week treatment period followed by a 48-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking speed is associated with postoperative pain catastrophizing in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: The study found that walking speed was significantly correlated with pain catastrophizing, leg pain, back pain, and functional scores at all postoperative evaluation points, suggesting walking speed is a useful assessment for managing pain and disability after lumbar spine surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with clinically and radiologically defined lumbar spinal stenosis undergoing surgical treatment.
study_duration: Evaluations were conducted preoperatively and at 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a theory-based, Internet-delivered behavioral intervention promoting physical activity could improve function, symptoms, and quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced fatigue severity and physical fatigue impact scores compared to the control group, with effects sustained over a 6-month follow-up. No significant improvements were observed in other patient-reported outcomes like walking, cognitive function, or other symptoms.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) in the United States (N = 318).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional outcomes, complication rates, and survival in patients with intertrochanteric fractures treated with percutaneous compression plate (PCCP) or gamma nail (GN).
results_summary: Walking ability and ADLs decreased, and the need for walking aids increased in both groups post-fracture, with no significant differences between PCCP and GN in complication rates or one-year survival.
population_specificity: Patients with AO/OTA 31.A1 or AO/OTA 31.A2 intertrochanteric fractures.
study_duration: Follow-up at 4 months and 1 year post-fracture fixation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of partnered rhythmic rehabilitation (PRR) versus group walking (WALK) for improving motor-cognitive integration in individuals with prodromal Alzheimer's disease (pAD).
results_summary: The study will assess the acceptability, safety, and tolerability of PRR and compare its efficacy to WALK for improving motor-cognitive integration, with additional exploration of neural, vascular, and inflammatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: 66 patients with prodromal Alzheimer's disease (pAD).
effective_dosage: Biweekly sessions for three months, followed by weekly sessions for nine months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if individualized treatment selection using CARTA improved gait dynamics and reduced tendon elongation compared to standard treatments in Achilles rupture patients.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in ankle peak power during push-off or tendon elongation between patients treated with CARTA and those receiving standard non-operative or operative treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with Achilles rupture (156 assessed, 60 allocated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dynamic multi-domain assessment paradigms used to evaluate concussion recovery, with a focus on combinations of physical (e.g., walking) and cognitive tasks.
results_summary: The study found that dual-task assessments, particularly level walking combined with Q&A cognitive tasks, were the most frequently implemented approach for evaluating concussion recovery. These multi-domain assessments were used across 46 studies involving 1938 concussed participants.
population_specificity: Youth and adults recovering from concussion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether RT234, an inhaled phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor, could increase oxygen capacity during cardiopulmonary exercise testing in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of RT234 on exercise parameters, as the study is ongoing and expected to be completed by early 2024.
population_specificity: Patients with right heart catheterization-confirmed PAH, a 6-minute walking distance of ≥ 150 m, and on up to three stable oral/inhaled PAH-specific background therapies.
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg and 1.0 mg RT234 (two dose cohorts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional, radiological, and gait outcomes between medial pivot (MP) and posterior-stabilised (PS) knee designs in total knee arthroplasty patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in range of motion, patient-reported outcomes, walking speed, length of stay, radiographic alignment, or complication rates between MP and PS knee designs. Both designs showed comparable performance across all measured parameters.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (1101 patients, 1242 TKAs).
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 6 months to 6.6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of IoT-based telerehabilitation (including power cycling and neuromuscular exercise) on pain and walking function in middle-aged and elderly patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The study assessed pain, physical function, walking ability, and quality of life using standardized scales (WOMAC, numerical pain rating, timed up and go test, 6-minute walk test). Results suggest potential improvements in these outcomes, but specific findings are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly patients (≥50 years) with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved power cycling and neuromuscular exercise, but exact dosage/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether insular damage in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients affects cardiovascular fitness and whether aerobic training (AT) can improve walking capacity and cardiovascular fitness in these patients.
results_summary: MS patients showed impaired cardiovascular fitness compared to healthy controls. Aerobic training improved 6-minute walk test performance, particularly in patients without insular T2-hyperintense lesions, and helped stabilize insular volume, whereas the control group showed volume loss.
population_specificity: 61 multiple sclerosis (MS) patients, with additional healthy control groups for comparison.
effective_dosage: 24 sessions over 2-3 months (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of single-task and dual-task balance exercise programs on balance performance and activity-specific balance confidence in older adults with Lumbar Spinal Stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Both single- and dual-task exercises improved static balance, dynamic balance, and activity-specific balance confidence in older adults with LSS. However, the dual-task exercise program was superior in improving 10-meter walk test scores and walking speed, with or without cognitive dual-tasking.
population_specificity: Adults over 65 years old with Lumbar Spinal Stenosis (LSS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (balance exercises performed under single- or dual-task conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify digital biomarkers of gait and balance dysfunction in people with diabetic foot using wearable IMUs and assess their clinical applicability.
results_summary: The study found preliminary evidence of digital biomarkers (e.g., slow gait speed, large gait variability) in diabetic foot patients but noted heterogeneity in study designs and small sample sizes, recommending further research.
population_specificity: People with diabetic foot

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of mobility and positional changes on perinatal and neonatal outcomes in individuals with epidural analgesia during labor.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefits or detrimental effects of mobilization on mode of birth, duration of labor, or extrauterine adaptation after birth. Heterogeneity was observed in the types of movement interventions used during labor stages.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals in labor with epidural analgesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the available evidence on the use of Robotic Assisted Gait Training (RAGT) in post-stroke patients, following CICERONE Consensus indications.
results_summary: The review identified 61 articles, highlighting variability in RAGT protocols and doses but suggested that certain robotic devices are more suitable for specific disease phases and disability levels. RAGT as an add-on treatment appeared prevalent, though further studies are needed to investigate outcomes based on RAGT doses.
population_specificity: Adult post-stroke survivors with gait disability in acute, subacute, or chronic phases.
effective_dosage: Not specified (significant variability in dose and protocols noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with l-arginine plus vitamin C could improve walking performance, muscle strength, endothelial function, and fatigue in adults with long COVID.
results_summary: The study found that l-arginine plus vitamin C significantly increased the 6-minute walk distance, improved handgrip strength, enhanced flow-mediated dilation, and reduced fatigue compared to placebo in adults with long COVID.
population_specificity: Adults aged 20-60 years with persistent fatigue attending a post-acute COVID-19 outpatient clinic.
effective_dosage: 1.66 g l-arginine plus 500 mg liposomal vitamin C, twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and effectiveness of a 3-month coaching-based teleoccupational guidance (CTG) programme for home-based stroke survivors and their family caregivers.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention.
population_specificity: Home-based stroke survivors and their family caregivers (25 participant dyads).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of intravenous iron supplementation (ferric carboxymaltose) on cardiac performance and endothelial function in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), using a 6-minute walking test (6MWT) as a measure.
results_summary: The study evaluated the impact of iron supplementation on walking capacity (6MWT), diastolic function, endothelial dysfunction, and oxidative stress biomarkers in HFpEF patients, but specific results regarding walking improvements were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 64 subjects with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and iron deficiency.
effective_dosage: Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) administered intravenously (exact dosage not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of gait-specific training on corticospinal excitability in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Some studies showed improvements in corticospinal excitability measures (e.g., increased MEP amplitude, decreased latency) after gait-specific training, but methodological disparities and mixed results highlight the need for further high-quality trials.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers were not studying walking; they focused on the therapeutic potential of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs) for treating diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: The abstract does not report any findings related to walking; it discusses BMSC transplantation's effects on wound healing, pain scores, and claudication walking distances in DFU patients.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise training, including walking, improves exercise capacity, quality of life, and lung function in patients with pulmonary fibrosis (PF).
results_summary: Exercise training significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, forced vital capacity, forced expiratory volume, and maximal oxygen consumption in PF patients, but did not significantly affect quality of life or lung diffusing capacity.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary fibrosis (PF) (n=456).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of Shexiang Baoxin Pill combined with home-based exercise training in improving exercise tolerance, sleep quality, and quality of life in heart failure patients with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: Exercise training improved exercise tolerance, sleep quality, and quality of life in HFpEF patients. Shexiang Baoxin Pill further enhanced sleep quality and quality of life when combined with exercise.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with heart failure and preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a targeted gluteal intervention could restore normal gluteal muscle segment activity during gait in people with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The targeted gluteal intervention led to decreased average and peak muscle activity in posterior GMin during late stance phase, with an earlier time to peak, resembling patterns in healthy young populations. No significant changes were observed in other muscle segments.
population_specificity: People with radiologically confirmed mild-moderate hip osteoarthritis.

study_goal: To compare the effects of lower limb loading training (LLLT) with or without augmented loading feedback on mobility, walking device use, and falls in ambulatory individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Mobility outcomes significantly improved from baseline, particularly in the group receiving augmented feedback (1.8s faster in timed up and go). The training program improved mobility, walking ability, and reduced fall rates, with greater benefits observed in the feedback group.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals with chronic spinal cord injury (post-injury time ~4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and clinical efficacy of NMN supplementation on blood NAD concentration and physical performance (measured via a six-minute walking test) in middle-aged healthy adults.
results_summary: NMN supplementation significantly increased blood NAD levels and improved walking distance in the six-minute walking test, with the highest efficacy observed at 600 mg daily. The treatment was safe and well-tolerated, with no reported adverse events or safety concerns.
population_specificity: Middle-aged healthy adults (80 participants).
effective_dosage: 300 mg, 600 mg, or 900 mg NMN once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dorsal root ganglion stimulation (DRGS) in improving functional outcomes, including walking distance, for patients with chronic postsurgical knee pain.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking distance (from 125 meters to 1481 meters), pain reduction, and quality of life, with 73% of participants ceasing opioid or other pain medications.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic postsurgical knee pain who had undergone an interdisciplinary multimodal pain program.

study_goal: The researchers sought to compare the efficacy of eccentric resistance training (ERT) against conventional therapeutic modalities or weightlifting on walking speed, Timed Up and Go (TUG), and maximum voluntary isometric contraction (MVIC) in individuals with neurological conditions.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between ERT and traditional therapies or weightlifting on measured outcomes (TUG, MVIC, walking speed), suggesting ERT is as effective as traditional methods for improving movement in clinical populations. ERT may be preferable due to lower metabolic demand and greater work volume capacity.
population_specificity: Individuals with neurological conditions (n = 297 across 13 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and define gait characteristics immediately following a concussion to improve identification, management, and prognosis.
results_summary: The study found that multiple gait features, such as stability, step length, walking speed, and postural control, are altered post-concussion. Dynamic gait and postural assessments can identify more subtle deficits, but there is a lack of data on immediate changes post-impact.
population_specificity: Individuals post-concussion (mTBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the failure rate, clinical outcomes, and complications of extensor mechanism reconstruction using Achilles tendon allograft (ATA) and extensor mechanism allograft (EMA) in patients following total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found an overall failure rate of 23% for allograft reconstruction, with EMA associated with fewer patients requiring walking aids (34.5%) compared to ATA (55%). Persistent extensor lag was the most common complication, and both graft types showed comparable clinical outcomes in patellar tendon ruptures.
population_specificity: Patients with extensor mechanism rupture following TKA, mean age ranging from 54 to 74 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathogenesis of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, including its respiratory and extrapulmonary effects, to guide prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The study summarized that M. pneumoniae causes respiratory and extrapulmonary damage through adhesion, direct invasion, inflammation, immune evasion, and vascular occlusion, though the exact mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of M. pneumoniae infection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a shoe sole with a shock-absorbing modification could reduce knee pain compared to a traditional sole during walking.
results_summary: Participants using the intervention sole shoe reported an 85% reduction in knee pain, significantly better than those using the traditional sole shoe, whose pain scores increased. Positive effects on back and foot pain were also observed with the intervention sole.
population_specificity: Fifty-two adults with overuse symptoms of knee pain, either unilateral or bilateral.
effective_dosage: Not specified (shoes worn as usual during daily activities)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness and safety of pirfenidone in treating idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that pirfenidone reduced declines in lung function and improved progression-free survival in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis patients, but with higher incidence of adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, including those with Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome-related pulmonary fibrosis and moderate idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate energy expenditure measures of walking on level, uphill, and downhill slopes in people with multiple sclerosis (pwMS) compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found that oxygen rate and cost were higher during uphill walking and lower during downhill walking compared to level walking for both pwMS and healthy controls. pwMS had lower oxygen rate and net oxygen cost during uphill walking compared to healthy controls and perceived uphill walking as more demanding despite lower energy expenditure values.
population_specificity: Eighteen people with multiple sclerosis (10 women, 8 men, mean age 39.7) and 23 healthy adults (8 women, 15 men, mean age 37.1).
study_duration: Each walking trial lasted 6 minutes, separated by 10-minute recovery intervals.

study_goal: To examine the effect of early mobility (walking) on functional recovery after hip fracture surgery and identify factors delaying mobility.
results_summary: Early mobility improved walking ability, independence in daily activities, and home discharge rates. Early physiotherapy intervention was linked to better mobility outcomes.
population_specificity: 110 hip fracture patients post-surgery.
study_duration: Assessed at postoperative days 7 and 14, and time to discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of community-based non-pharmacological interventions, including walking, for managing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: Postprandial blood glucose levels were better improved by regular supervised exercise plus daily brisk walks or a daily walking intervention compared to routine obstetric care or no treatment. However, the effects of exercise/physical activity programs were inconsistent for other outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
effective_dosage: Daily brisk walks or a daily walking intervention (specific duration/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how depressive symptoms mediate the effects of physical and cognitive decline, including walking speed, on disability in older adults.
results_summary: Depressive symptoms significantly exacerbated the effects of worsening cognition, gait speed, and comorbidities on disability, with depressive symptoms mediating 34% of the effect of mobility on disability. Even subclinical depressive symptoms were linked to increased disability.
population_specificity: 223 adults aged 50-85 (117 controls and 106 with type-2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation and patient perspectives of ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) use for improving walking ability in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) six months post-intervention.
results_summary: Patients found the AFO device easy to use initially and cost-effective, but motivation for sustained use was hindered by challenges in observability and relative advantage. Barriers to long-term AFO use included device interference with common activities and poor health.
population_specificity: Male patients (N=7; age 71.9±0.6.7y; BMI 29.0±0.5.5) with PAD and claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of physical exercise, particularly walking programs, on reducing fear of falling in individuals with stroke.
results_summary: Walking programs showed a larger effect on reducing fear of falling (SMD 1.06) compared to circuit-based training (SMD 0.27). The effect was more pronounced in individuals with poorer baseline balance (BBS ≤45) and for those exercising ≥3 sessions per week.
population_specificity: Individuals with stroke
effective_dosage: ≥3 sessions per week (specific duration per session not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of oral NMN supplementation in improving grip strength and walking speed in older male patients with diabetes and impaired physical performance.
results_summary: NMN supplementation was found to be safe with no severe adverse events, but it did not significantly improve grip strength or walking speed compared to placebo. Some exploratory indicators, like frailty prevalence and central retinal thickness, showed marginal improvements but were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Older male patients (aged ≥65 years) with diabetes and reduced grip strength (<26 kg) or walking speed (<1.0 m/s).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Baduanjin exercise on quality of life and exercise capacity in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: Baduanjin exercise significantly improved overall quality of life and exercise capacity in heart failure patients, with notable improvements in physical, emotional, and general quality of life domains. The results were statistically significant, though marked heterogeneity was observed.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the distance of gait training using a hybrid assistive limb (HAL) is related to improvements in walking independence in patients with acute brain injury.
results_summary: The study found that patients who achieved longer gait distances during HAL training showed greater improvements in walking independence (FAC score). Group C (FAC improvement ≥2) had significantly longer gait distances than Group A (no improvement).
population_specificity: Thirty patients with hemiplegia (FAC score ≤2) due to acute stroke or brain tumor surgery.
effective_dosage: 4 sessions of gait training (60 min/session), 1-3 sessions/week.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but intervention involved 4 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of home-based exercises (including walking) on motor, cognitive, or health-related quality of life outcomes in Huntington's disease.
results_summary: The study reviewed randomized controlled trials and used standardized mean differences to assess the impact of home-based exercises, but specific results regarding walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with Huntington's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate union rates, reoperation rates, and patient-reported outcomes (EQ-VAS and DRI scores) following treatment of open tibial fractures with a Taylor Spatial Frame (TSF) and combined orthoplastic approach.
results_summary: The study found that 80.4% of patients achieved union, but 45.1% required a walking aid at 1 year post-op, and EQ-VAS and DRI scores significantly deteriorated, indicating long recovery periods and significant morbidity.
population_specificity: Patients with high-energy open tibial fractures treated at a level 1 major trauma center (mean age 51.2 years, 4:1 male preponderance).
study_duration: Mean time in frame was 206.7 ± 149.4 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical risk factors for hip fractures and assess functional outcomes post-fracture in a South African population.
results_summary: The study found that clinical risk factors for hip fractures in South Africa were similar to those in high-income countries, with poor functional outcomes post-fracture, including significant declines in independence and increased dependency. Walking up stairs and transferring from bed to chair were the most affected activities post-fracture.
population_specificity: 287 subjects (median age 72 years, 67.2% women) from two municipalities in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, with a majority having two or more comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review barriers, facilitators, and preferences for exercise, including walking, among cancer survivors.
results_summary: Walking was identified as the preferred method of exercise among cancer survivors, with key barriers including treatment-related side effects, lack of time, and fatigue, while facilitators included improved health control and mental well-being.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility and efficacy of a telephone-based motor imagery intervention for improving gait in healthy elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results but focused on establishing feasibility and exploring efficacy, with primary outcomes being gait speed during actual walking and walking while talking, and secondary outcomes including cognitive performance and functional neuroplasticity.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly individuals (48 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified (involved imagined walking, imagined talking, and imagined walking while talking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility of a 6-month yoga program to improve physical and psychosocial status, including walking speed, in persons with MS and their family members.
results_summary: The study found that walking speed significantly improved in persons with MS after the yoga program, but there was no significant change in self-reported walking impact. No significant improvements were observed in balance or other physical dimensions.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) and their healthy family members.
effective_dosage: Yoga training once a week (at least 1 hour).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of an individually tailored, Internet-mediated physical activity intervention for increasing walking behavior in inactive older adults.
results_summary: Both the pedometer-only (PED) and tailored Internet-mediated pedometer (TI-PED) groups significantly increased step counts compared to the control group, with the TI-PED group showing higher step counts than the PED group at 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Inactive older adults (N = 170).
effective_dosage: Participants were instructed to increase weekly step count by 10% until achieving 10,000 steps per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of exercise physiologist coaching (face-to-face and telephone) in increasing physical activity (step count) among sedentary patients in general practice.
results_summary: At 12 months, both intervention groups showed a modest increase in activity (1,002 steps/day more than controls), equivalent to 10 minutes of walking daily, at a cost of AUD$245 per person. No change in quality of life or utility values was observed.
population_specificity: Sedentary patients seen in general practice (Australia).
study_duration: 12 weeks of coaching, with follow-up at 3 and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of footwear interventions on foot pain, function, impairment, and disability in people with foot and ankle arthritis.
results_summary: Footwear interventions reduced foot pain, impairment, and disability in rheumatoid arthritis, improved foot pain, function, and disability in gout, and enhanced foot pain and function in 1st metatarsophalangeal joint osteoarthritis. They also reduced plantar pressure and improved walking velocity in these conditions.
population_specificity: People with rheumatoid arthritis, gout, and 1st metatarsophalangeal joint osteoarthritis.
study_duration: Varied, with shorter follow-up periods (e.g., 12 weeks) noted for some outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of an Adapted Physical Activity (APA) program, including walking, on hospital stay, mortality, morbidity, and secondary outcomes like physical fitness in adults with End Stage Liver Disease (ESLD) before Liver Transplantation (LT).
results_summary: The study found no severe adverse events from APA, and physical activity did not worsen CHILD, MELD, or BMI scores. A significant reduction in Hepatic Venous Pressure Gradient (HVPG) was observed in one study, but no significant changes were noted in muscle diameter, 6-minute walking distance, or VO2 peak.
population_specificity: Adults with End Stage Liver Disease (ESLD) awaiting Liver Transplantation (LT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of high-intensity, one-legged cycling training on vascular function, exercise capacity, and the ability to override sympathetic vasoconstriction in heart failure patients compared to healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that high-intensity, one-legged cycling improved aerobic capacity in both heart failure patients and healthy individuals, and specifically improved 6-minute walking distance in heart failure patients. The ability to override sympathetic vasoconstriction during exercise was not different between groups and improved with training, while the peak vasodilatory response to ATP was blunted in heart failure patients.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction (n=8) and healthy individuals (n=6).
effective_dosage: High-intensity, one-legged cycling (8 × 4 at 90% one-legged cycling max).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine correlates of active school transportation (AST) in North America and assess trends and factors influencing school travel mode choices over time.
results_summary: The study found that distance to school was the strongest correlate of AST, with moderate positive associations for child age, parental education, income, race, and perceptions of AST. It highlighted a lack of longitudinal studies and interventions targeting AST.
population_specificity: Children in North America (studies from 1990-2016).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a physical activity-oriented home rehabilitation program (ProPA) on increasing physical activity and restoring mobility in older adults after hospitalization for musculoskeletal injuries.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the ProPA program, which includes motivational interviews, goal setting, walking guidance, and exercise counseling, but final results on efficacy are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 60+ hospitalized for musculoskeletal injuries or disorders in the back or lower limbs.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program includes progressive home exercises and activity counseling).
